Bitcoin has practically no need for governance. If you agree with the rules you stay, if you disagree, you leave and start your own project. I'm afraid governance friendly blockchains are a can of worms.

So Christopher Allen co-authored the TLS standard. Bram Cohen created BitTorrent. Adam Back invented proof of work. Those are people that are obvious follows for me. I'm asking if there are engineers with comparable pedigree who are working on Ethereum.

I'm not saying there are no world class developers in cryptocurrency if we can't find prior high pedigree achievements. Absence of proof is no proof of absence. But identification and agreement is much harder without fairly uncontroversial achievements to reference.

Evaluating quality/robustness of tech is easier with the benefit of hindsight. Many new developments in cryptocurrency are interesting but their robustness still very much unproven. So for me to ask about prior achievements is a way to approximate dev quality.

Thanks. To help identify particular individuals as world class with some objectivity, could you please list prior documented and highly respected achievements in areas of cryptography, p2p protocols, internet protocols, memory compression, or large open source projects?

I agree though that using the term cryptofiat may further confuse the situation though. Perhaps just digital fiat?
No, ETFs don’t represent a new asset class. They are wrappers around other asset classes. Fiat falls under the traditional currency asset class which is not part of cryptoassets, no matter the form.
8/ Fiat is fiat, no matter the form, and certainly doesn’t deserve to stand among the ranks of cryptocurrencies like bitcoin, monero, zcash, decred, and more.
7/ Cryptocurrencies are part of a new asset class with brand new manifestations of governance & supply schedules, and given their programmability have use case potential that dwarfs fiat.
6/ Cryptofiat will fall under the same governance, succumb to the same inflationary supply schedule, and target the same use cases as physical fiat.

4/ I wrote about key differentiators for asset classes in the summer of 2016, and what falls under the umbrella of cryptoasset (though we weren’t using that term at the time): http:// research.ark-invest.com/bitcoin-asset- class …
2/ Instead, a (relatively) new technology is being used to provision an old asset. Instead of lumping this under the cryptocurrency umbrella, I propose using #cryptofiat .
